results.title: Hamburger hill
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, Nasitir-Carabatsos, Interaccess, Marcia Nasatir, Jim Carabatos and John irvin
results.brief_description: Set during the Vietnamese conflict in 1969, “Hamburger Hill” is a realistic, horrific dramatic depiction, almost documentary-like in format, of one of the bloodiest battles of the Vietnam War. The film follows the fortunes of 14 recruits through 10 days of hell as they make repeated assaults on a heavily fortified hill. The developing relationships between the young soldiers is tested by the grim realities of war and death. “Hamburger Hill” is a moving tribute to the men who fought a futile campaign which resulted in 70% of casualties.
results.creator_credit_for_label: RKO Radio Pictures, Nasitir-Carabatsos, Interaccess, Marcia Nasatir, Jim Carabatos and John irvin

results.title: Halloween (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Falcon Film, Debra Hill and John Carpenter
results.brief_description: John Carpenter’s much imitated Halloween defined the eighties stalk and slash genre, spawning inferior copies like the Friday the 13th series (including six sequels of it’s own) and for a time making star Jamie Lee Curtis into the premium ‘scream queen’. Later on the conventions of the genre were cleverly re-invented for a nineties audience by director Wes Craven and writer Kevin Williamson in Scream, which pays direct homage to Halloween. John Carpenter opens his film with an unnerving point of view shot of the young psychotic Michael Myers brutally stabbing his teenage sister to death on Halloween night. Flash forward to Halloween 15 years later and Michael has escaped the mental institution he has been locked up in. Meanwhile shy, virginal teenager Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) and her girlfriends are preparing for Halloween, unaware of the menace that lurks in their quiet suburban community. Carpenter makes great use of the sparse, atmospheric music score (which he also composed) and uses to maximum creepy effect the white mask Michael Myers wears throughout the film. The film also established the classic horror genre rule if your a sexually active teenager, you die! Also staring: Donald Pleasence, P.J. Soles, Tony Moran.

results.title: Half a sixpence
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Charles H. Schneer and George Sidney
results.brief_description: Based on the H.G. Wells novel ‘Kipps’, Tommy Steele stars as Arthur Kipp, a young draper’s assistant who inherits a fortune and enters Edwardian society. Arthur finds out that wealth doesn’t necessarily buy happiness. Apart from the lavish costumes, this production features some big numbers such as the title song and the wonderful “What a picture’. Also stars Julia Foster.

results.title: Hairspray
results.creator_credit: New Line Cinema, Rachel Talalay and John Waters
results.brief_description: The frenzied, all-out dancing, all rockin’ rememberance of Baltimore 1962. A time infested with glamour crazed teens to whom TV was everything. Featuring an electric combination of talents that include Divine, Sonny Bono and Debbie Harry, set around Baltimore’s coolest pop show, “The Corny Collins Show”. Happy teen viewers thrill to watching their towns’ coolest teens rock to the country’s trendiest new dances. One such viewer is Tracy Turnblad, a tubby teenager who lives her dream by getting her big shot on the show. However, Tracy finds herself in bitter competition with the show’s reigning teen queen, bitchy Amber Von Tussle. They battle not only for the crown but also for the true love of teen hunk, Link.

details.label: Subject categories
display_values: Feature films → Feature films - United States

results.title: Hair
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Lester Persky, Michael Butler and Milos Forman
results.brief_description: Despite the sceptics, Milos Forman transformed the ultimate “tribal rock musical” of the 1960’s into an exuberant film experience. The score is performed in a variety of locations including table tops, Central Park, Wall Street and in march formation aboard a plane heading for Vietnam. “Hair” is not just a nostalgic look at the ‘60’s and “The Age of Aquarius”, but the ideals it espouses about peace, individual freedom, joy and love are just as passionate and relevant today, as they were shocking and radical at the time of America’s involvement in Vietnam. Gerome Ragni and James Rado worked on this film production of their original stageplay.

results.title: Hail Mary = Je Vous salue Marie
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, Television Romande, Channel 4 and Jean-Luc Godard
results.brief_description: This amazingly moving, funny yet disturbing, richly human film has aroused passionate feelings right around the world. Mary, the young daughter of a petrol station owner who is just beginning to discover womanhood, and her taxi driver, Joseph, try to grapple with her unexplained pregnancy.

results.title: Gypsy
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Mervyn LeRoy and Orry-Kelly
results.brief_description: Gypsy Rose Lee, burlesque Queen of renown, was driven to stardom much less by her own ambition, than by the ruthless determination of her mother. As the stereotypical domineering “stage mother”, Rosalind Russell’s performance is superb, while Karl Malden as her long-suffering but loyal lover also gives a fine performance. While the references to striptease are undeniably fleeting, Natalie Wood as Gypsy Rose Lee is creditable, but it is her vulnerability rather than her sex appeal which comes to the fore. Stephen Sondheim’s lyrics and Julie Styne’s score makes this a musical delight.

results.title: Guys and dolls
results.creator_credit: Samuel Goldwyn Productions, Samuel Goldwyn and Joseph L Mankiewicz
results.brief_description: Adapted from a short story by Damon Runyan about a pair of ne’er to do gamblers trying to snare a jackpot amidst the clutter of Times Square as well as the affections of two women. The excellent score by Frank Loesser includes “Luck be a lady”, “If I were a bell” and Stubby Kaye’s show stopper “Sitdown, you’re rocking the boat.” Choreographer Michale Kidd brought the dances full of flash and vitality to the screen. Starring Marlon Brando, Frank Sinatra, Jean Simmons and Vivian Blaine.
